onContentChanged().Description: Called when @B_android#content#Loader#ForceLoadContentObserver_E@ detects a change. The default implementation checks to see if the loader is currently started; if so, it simply calls @B_android#content#Loader#forceLoad_E@; otherwise, it sets a flag so that @B_android#content#Loader#takeContentChanged_E@ returns true. Must be called from the process's main thread.
onContentChanged().history: Added in API level 11 Deprecated in API level 28

deliverCancellation().Description: Informs the registered @B_android#content#Loader#OnLoadCanceledListener_E@ that the load has been canceled. Should only be called by subclasses. Must be called from the process's main thread.
deliverCancellation().history: Added in API level 16 Deprecated in API level 28

Returns: Returns false if the task could not be canceled, typically because it has already completed normally, or because @B_android#content#Loader#startLoading_E@ hasn't been called; returns true otherwise. When true is returned, the task is still running and the @B_android#content#Loader#OnLoadCanceledListener_E@ will be called when the task completes.
cancelLoad().Description: Attempt to cancel the current load task. Must be called on the main thread of the process. Cancellation is not an immediate operation, since the load is performed in a background thread. If there is currently a load in progress, this method requests that the load be canceled, and notes this is the case; once the background thread has completed its work its remaining state will be cleared. If another load request comes in during this time, it will be held until the canceled load is complete.
cancelLoad().history: Added in API level 16 Deprecated in API level 28

isAbandoned().Description: Return whether this loader has been abandoned. In this state, the loader must not report any new data, and must keep its last reported data valid until it is finally reset.
isAbandoned().history: Added in API level 11 Deprecated in API level 28

stopLoading().Description: This function will normally be called for you automatically by @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@ when the associated fragment/activity is being stopped. When using a Loader with @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@, you must not call this method yourself, or you will conflict with its management of the Loader. Stops delivery of updates until the next time @B_android#content#Loader#startLoading_E@ is called. Implementations should not invalidate their data at this point -- clients are still free to use the last data the loader reported. They will, however, typically stop reporting new data if the data changes; they can still monitor for changes, but must not report them to the client until and if @B_android#content#Loader#startLoading_E@ is later called. This updates the Loader's internal state so that @B_android#content#Loader#isStarted_E@ will return the correct value, and then calls the implementation's @B_android#content#Loader#onStopLoading_E@. Must be called from the process's main thread.
stopLoading().history: Added in API level 11 Deprecated in API level 28

unregisterOnLoadCanceledListener(android.history: Added in API level 16 Deprecated in API level 28

forceLoad().Description: Force an asynchronous load. Unlike @B_android#content#Loader#startLoading_E@ this will ignore a previously loaded data set and load a new one. This simply calls through to the implementation's @B_android#content#Loader#onForceLoad_E@. You generally should only call this when the loader is started -- that is, @B_android#content#Loader#isStarted_E@ returns true. Must be called from the process's main thread.

Call this when you have completely processed a load without it being cancelled.

onAbandon().Description: Subclasses implement this to take care of being abandoned. This is an optional intermediate state prior to @B_android#content#Loader#onReset_E@ -- it means that the client is no longer interested in any new data from the loader, so the loader must not report any further updates. However, the loader must keep its last reported data valid until the final @B_android#content#Loader#onReset_E@ happens. You can retrieve the current abandoned state with @B_android#content#Loader#isAbandoned_E@.

reset().Description: This function will normally be called for you automatically by @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@ when destroying a Loader. When using a Loader with @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@, you must not call this method yourself, or you will conflict with its management of the Loader. Resets the state of the Loader. The Loader should at this point free all of its resources, since it may never be called again; however, its @B_android#content#Loader#startLoading_E@ may later be called at which point it must be able to start running again. This updates the Loader's internal state so that @B_android#content#Loader#isStarted_E@ and @B_android#content#Loader#isReset_E@ will return the correct values, and then calls the implementation's @B_android#content#Loader#onReset_E@. Must be called from the process's main thread.

onReset().Description: Subclasses must implement this to take care of resetting their loader, as per @B_android#content#Loader#reset_E@. Returns: a string representation of the object.
toString().Description: Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method. The toString method for class Object returns a string consisting of the name of the class of which the object is an instance, the at-sign character `@', and the unsigned hexadecimal representation of the hash code of the object. In other words, this method returns a string equal to the value of:

abandon().Description: This function will normally be called for you automatically by @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@ when restarting a Loader. When using a Loader with @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@, you must not call this method yourself, or you will conflict with its management of the Loader. Tell the Loader that it is being abandoned. This is called prior to @B_android#content#Loader#reset_E@ to have it retain its current data but not report any new data.

startLoading().Description: This function will normally be called for you automatically by @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@ when the associated fragment/activity is being started. When using a Loader with @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@, you must not call this method yourself, or you will conflict with its management of the Loader. Starts an asynchronous load of the Loader's data. When the result is ready the callbacks will be called on the process's main thread. If a previous load has been completed and is still valid the result may be passed to the callbacks immediately. The loader will monitor the source of the data set and may deliver future callbacks if the source changes. Calling @B_android#content#Loader#stopLoading_E@ will stop the delivery of callbacks. This updates the Loader's internal state so that @B_android#content#Loader#isStarted_E@ and @B_android#content#Loader#isReset_E@ will return the correct values, and then calls the implementation's @B_android#content#Loader#onStartLoading_E@. Must be called from the process's main thread.
startLoading().history: Added in API level 11 Deprecated in API level 28

Parameters: Context: used to retrieve the application context.
Loader(android.content.Context).Description: Stores away the application context associated with context. Since Loaders can be used across multiple activities it's dangerous to store the context directly; always use @B_android#content#Loader#getContext_E@ to retrieve the Loader's Context, don't use the constructor argument directly. The Context returned by @B_android#content#Loader#getContext_E@ is safe to use across Activity instances.

ClassDesc: Use the https:##developer#android#com@B_android#support#v4#content#Loader_E@ A class that performs asynchronous loading of data. While Loaders are active they should monitor the source of their data and deliver new results when the contents change. See @B_android#app#LoaderManager_E@ for more detail. @B_android#content#AsyncTaskLoader_E@) will often perform their work in a separate thread, but when delivering their results this too should be done on the main thread. Subclasses generally must implement at least @B_android#content#Loader#onStartLoading_E@, @B_android#content#Loader#onStopLoading_E@, @B_android#content#Loader#onForceLoad_E@, and @B_android#content#Loader#onReset_E@. Most implementations should not derive directly from this class, but instead inherit from @B_android#content#AsyncTaskLoader_E@.
